sn12.8:1.1.eng: “Koṇāgamana, the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha …”

sn12.82:1.2.pli: “Jarāmaraṇaṃ, bhikkhave, ajānatā apassatā yathābhūtaṃ jarāmaraṇe yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇāya satthā pariyesitabbo;
sn12.82:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, one who does not truly know or see old age and death should seek the Teacher so as to truly know old age and death.

sn12.82:1.3.pli: jarāmaraṇasamudayaṃ ajānatā apassatā yathābhūtaṃ jarāmaraṇasamudaye yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇāya satthā pariyesitabbo;
sn12.82:1.3.eng: One who does not truly know or see the origin of old age and death should seek the Teacher so as to truly know the origin of old age and death.

sn12.82:1.4.pli: jarāmaraṇanirodhaṃ ajānatā apassatā yathābhūtaṃ jarāmaraṇanirodhe yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇāya satthā pariyesitabbo;
sn12.82:1.4.eng: One who does not truly know or see the cessation of old age and death should seek the Teacher so as to truly know the cessation of old age and death.

sn12.82:1.5.pli: jarāmaraṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ ajānatā apassatā yathābhūtaṃ jarāmaraṇanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇāya satthā pariyesitabbo”ti.
sn12.82:1.5.eng: One who does not truly know or see the practice that leads to the cessation of old age and death should seek the Teacher so as to truly know the practice that leads to the cessation of old age and death.”

sn12.82:1.6.comm: This note is found in the Pali of the Mahāsaṅgīti edition, indicating that this is one discourse, and presumably that the following are reckoned as one discourse each. Bodhi counts them all together as a whole, so from here the numbering is out of sync with his.

sn12.82:1.8.eng: (All the abbreviated texts should be told in full.)

sn12.83:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, one who does not truly know or see rebirth …”

sn12.92:1.1.pli: “Saṅkhāre, bhikkhave, ajānatā apassatā yathābhūtaṃ saṅkhāresu yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇāya satthā pariyesitabbo;

sn12.92:1.2.pli: saṅkhārasamudayaṃ ajānatā apassatā yathābhūtaṃ saṅkhārasamudaye yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇāya satthā pariyesitabbo;

sn12.92:1.3.pli: saṅkhāranirodhaṃ ajānatā apassatā yathābhūtaṃ saṅkhāranirodhe yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇāya satthā pariyesitabbo;

sn12.92:1.4.pli: saṅkhāranirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ ajānatā apassatā yathābhūtaṃ saṅkhāranirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇāya satthā pariyesitabbo”ti.

sn12.92:1.6.eng: (All should be treated according to the four truths.)

sn12.9:1.1.eng: “Kassapa, the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha …”

sn12.93-103:0.3.eng: Sets of Eleven on Training, Etc.

sn12.93-103:1.1.pli: “Jarāmaraṇaṃ, bhikkhave, ajānatā apassatā yathābhūtaṃ jarāmaraṇe yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇāya sikkhā karaṇīyā.
sn12.93-103:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, one who does not truly know or see old age and death should train so as to truly know old age and death. …”

sn12.203-213:3.6.eng: The Linked Discourses on causality are complete.

sn13.1:1.1.comm: Although this chapter does not mention dependent origination, it is thematically linked. It depicts the realization of stream-entry as insight into Dhamma (SN 12.27:5.1), so that future rebirths are minimized (SN 12.41:2.1). The similes are also found in the Linked Discourses on the Truths (SN 56).

sn13.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn13.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn13.1:1.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā parittaṃ nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsuṃ āropetvā bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn13.1:1.3.eng: Then the Buddha, picking up a little bit of dirt on his fingernail, addressed the mendicants:
sn13.1:1.3.comm: The simile is used in the same application at SN 56.51; for the rareness of opportune rebirth at SN 20.2, SN 56.61, and SN 56.62; and for the absence of even a tiny bit of form that is permanent at SN 22.97.

sn13.1:1.5.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ, yo vāyaṃ mayā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito, ayaṃ vā mahāpathavī”ti?
sn13.1:1.5.eng: Which is more: the little bit of dirt on my fingernail, or this great earth?”

sn13.1:2.1.eng: “Sir, the great earth is far more.

sn13.1:2.2.pli: Appamattako bhagavatā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito.
sn13.1:2.2.eng: The little bit of dirt on your fingernail is tiny.

sn13.1:2.3.pli: Neva satimaṃ kalaṃ upeti na sahassimaṃ kalaṃ upeti na satasahassimaṃ kalaṃ upeti mahāpathaviṃ upanidhāya bhagavatā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito”ti.
sn13.1:2.3.eng: Compared to the great earth, it’s not nearly a hundredth, a thousandth, or a hundred thousandth part.”

sn13.1:2.4.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa diṭṭhisampannassa puggalassa abhisametāvino etadeva bahutaraṃ dukkhaṃ yadidaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ;
sn13.1:2.4.eng: “In the same way, for a noble disciple accomplished in view, an individual with comprehension, the suffering that’s over and done with is more,
sn13.1:2.4.comm: The diṭṭhisampanna is the stream-enterer. They are “accomplished in view” because they have directly seen the four noble truths and need no longer rely on faith in another.

sn13.1:2.6.pli: Neva satimaṃ kalaṃ upeti na sahassimaṃ kalaṃ upeti na satasahassimaṃ kalaṃ upeti purimaṃ dukkhakkhandhaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ upanidhāya yadidaṃ sattakkhattuṃparamatā.
sn13.1:2.6.eng: Compared to the mass of suffering in the past that’s over and done with, it’s not nearly a hundredth, a thousandth, or a hundred thousandth part, since there are at most seven more lives.
sn13.1:2.6.comm: For a stream-enterer, countless future lives of suffering have ceased, and only seven rebirths at most remain.

sn13.1:2.7.eng: That’s how very beneficial it is to comprehend the teaching
sn13.1:2.7.comm: The root sense of abhisamaya is “gathering”, as a group of brahmins for a congress (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 3.1.1), or as breaths to a dying man (4.4.1), or as winnings to the victor of the game (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 4.1.4). In Buddhism, it acquires the technical sense of the “comprehension” of the Dhamma at least at stream-entry. The English word “gather” has a similar meaning: to reach a conclusion by intuitively putting two and two together.

sn13.1:2.8.eng: and gain the vision of the teaching.”

sn13.10:1.2.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, himavā pabbatarājā parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya, ṭhapetvā satta sāsapamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā.
sn13.10:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, suppose the Himalayas, the king of mountains, was worn away and eroded except for seven pebbles the size of mustard seeds.

sn13.10:1.4.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ, yaṃ vā himavato pabbatarājassa parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ yā vā satta sāsapamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā avasiṭṭhā”ti?
sn13.10:1.4.eng: Which is more: the portion of the Himalayas, the king of mountains, that has been worn away and eroded, or the seven pebbles the size of mustard seeds that are left?”

sn13.10:2.1.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ himavato pabbatarājassa yadidaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ;
sn13.10:2.1.eng: “Sir, the portion of the Himalayas, the king of mountains, that has been worn away and eroded is certainly more.

sn13.10:2.2.eng: The seven pebbles the size of mustard seeds are tiny.

sn13.10:2.3.pli: Neva satimaṃ kalaṃ upenti na sahassimaṃ kalaṃ upenti na satasahassimaṃ kalaṃ upenti himavato pabbatarājassa parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ upanidhāya satta sāsapamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā avasiṭṭhā”ti.
sn13.10:2.3.eng: Compared to the Himalayas, it’s not nearly a hundredth, a thousandth, or a hundred thousandth part.”

sn13.10:3.1.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa diṭṭhisampannassa puggalassa abhisametāvino etadeva bahutaraṃ dukkhaṃ yadidaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ;
sn13.10:3.1.eng: “In the same way, for a noble disciple accomplished in view, an individual with comprehension, the suffering that’s over and done with is more,

sn13.10:3.3.pli: Neva satimaṃ kalaṃ upeti na sahassimaṃ kalaṃ upeti na satasahassimaṃ kalaṃ upeti purimaṃ dukkhakkhandhaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ upanidhāya yadidaṃ sattakkhattuṃparamatā.
sn13.10:3.3.eng: Compared to the mass of suffering in the past that’s over and done with, it’s not nearly a hundredth, a thousandth, or a hundred thousandth part, since there are at most seven more lives.

sn13.10:3.4.pli: Evaṃ mahatthiyo kho, bhikkhave, dhammābhisamayo, evaṃ mahatthiyo dhammacakkhupaṭilābho”ti.
sn13.10:3.4.eng: That’s how very beneficial it is to comprehend the teaching and gain the vision of the teaching.”

sn13.11:1.2.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso sinerussa pabbatarājassa satta muggamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā upanikkhipeyya.
sn13.11:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, suppose a person was to place on Sineru, the king of mountains, seven pebbles the size of mung beans.
sn13.11:1.2.comm: Sineru, also known as Neru (Ja 379:3.1), Meru (DN 32:7.2), or Sumeru (Thi Ap 17:53.2), is the axis mundi, the mountain around which the world revolves. The oldest reference is perhaps Taittiriya Āraṇyaka 1.7.1.3. Kaśyapa, the eighth above the seven Sūryas, dwells constantly on Meru, never leaving, while the other Suns illuminate different regions. Sages have gone as far as the regions around, but none reached the mountain itself.

sn13.11:1.4.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ, yā vā satta muggamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā upanikkhittā yo vā sineru pabbatarājā”ti?
sn13.11:1.4.eng: Which is more: the seven pebbles the size of mung beans, or Sineru, the king of mountains?”

sn13.11:2.1.eng: “Sir, Sineru, the king of mountains, is certainly more.

sn13.11:2.2.eng: The seven pebbles the size of mung beans are tiny.

sn13.11:2.3.pli: Neva satimaṃ kalaṃ upenti na sahassimaṃ kalaṃ upenti na satasahassimaṃ kalaṃ upenti sineruṃ pabbatarājānaṃ upanidhāya satta muggamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā upanikkhittā”ti.
sn13.11:2.3.eng: Compared to Sineru, it’s not nearly a hundredth, a thousandth, or a hundred thousandth part.”

sn13.11:3.1.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa diṭṭhisampannassa puggalassa adhigamaṃ upanidhāya aññatitthiyasamaṇabrāhmaṇaparibbājakānaṃ adhigamo neva satimaṃ kalaṃ upeti na sahassimaṃ kalaṃ upeti na satasahassimaṃ kalaṃ upeti.
sn13.11:3.1.eng: “In the same way, compared with the achievements of a noble disciple accomplished in view, the achievements of the ascetics, brahmins, and wanderers of other religions is not nearly a hundredth, a thousandth, or a hundred thousandth part.

sn13.11:3.2.pli: Evaṃ mahādhigamo, bhikkhave, diṭṭhisampanno puggalo, evaṃ mahābhiñño”ti.
sn13.11:3.2.eng: So great is the achievement of the individual accomplished in view, so great is their direct knowledge.”

sn13.11:3.4.eng: The Linked Discourses on comprehension are complete.

sn13.2:1.2.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, pokkharaṇī paññāsayojanāni āyāmena paññāsayojanāni vitthārena paññāsayojanāni ubbedhena, puṇṇā udakassa samatittikā kākapeyyā.
sn13.2:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, suppose there was a lotus pond that was fifty leagues long, fifty leagues wide, and fifty leagues deep, full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.

sn13.2:1.3.eng: Then a person would pick up some water on the tip of a blade of grass.

sn13.2:1.5.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ, yaṃ vā kusaggena udakaṃ ubbhataṃ yaṃ vā pokkharaṇiyā udakan”ti?
sn13.2:1.5.eng: Which is more: the water on the tip of the blade of grass, or the water in the lotus pond?”

sn13.2:2.1.eng: “Sir, the water in the lotus pond is certainly more.

sn13.2:2.2.eng: The water on the tip of a blade of grass is tiny.

sn13.2:2.3.pli: Neva satimaṃ kalaṃ upeti na sahassimaṃ kalaṃ upeti na satasahassimaṃ kalaṃ upeti pokkharaṇiyā udakaṃ upanidhāya kusaggena udakaṃ ubbhatan”ti.
sn13.2:2.3.eng: Compared to the water in the lotus pond, it’s not nearly a hundredth, a thousandth, or a hundred thousandth part.”

sn13.2:3.1.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa diṭṭhisampannassa puggalassa abhisametāvino etadeva bahutaraṃ dukkhaṃ yadidaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ; appamattakaṃ avasiṭṭhaṃ.
sn13.2:3.1.eng: “In the same way, for an individual with comprehension, a noble disciple accomplished in view, the suffering that’s over and done with is more, what’s left is tiny.

sn13.2:3.2.pli: Neva satimaṃ kalaṃ upeti na sahassimaṃ kalaṃ upeti na satasahassimaṃ kalaṃ upeti purimaṃ dukkhakkhandhaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ upanidhāya, yadidaṃ sattakkhattuṃparamatā.
sn13.2:3.2.eng: Compared to the mass of suffering in the past that’s over and done with, it’s not nearly a hundredth, a thousandth, or a hundred thousandth part, since there are at most seven more lives.

sn13.2:3.3.pli: Evaṃ mahatthiyo kho, bhikkhave, dhammābhisamayo; evaṃ mahatthiyo dhammacakkhupaṭilābho”ti.
sn13.2:3.3.eng: That’s how very beneficial it is to comprehend the teaching and gain the vision of the teaching.”

sn13.3:1.2.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yatthimā mahānadiyo saṃsandanti samenti, seyyathidaṃ—
sn13.3:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, there are places where the great rivers—the Ganges, Yamuna, Aciravatī, Sarabhū, and Mahī—join together and converge.

sn13.3:1.3.pli: gaṅgā yamunā aciravatī sarabhū mahī, tato puriso dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni uddhareyya.
sn13.3:1.3.eng: Suppose a person was to draw two or three drops of water from such a place.

sn13.3:1.5.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ, yāni vā dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni ubbhatāni yaṃ vā sambhejjaudakan”ti?
sn13.3:1.5.eng: Which is more: the two or three drops drawn out or the water in the confluence?”

sn13.3:2.1.eng: “Sir, the water in the confluence is certainly more.

sn13.3:2.2.pli: appamattakāni dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni ubbhatāni.
sn13.3:2.2.eng: The two or three drops drawn out are tiny.

sn13.3:2.3.pli: Neva satimaṃ kalaṃ upenti na sahassimaṃ kalaṃ upenti na satasahassimaṃ kalaṃ upenti sambhejjaudakaṃ upanidhāya dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni ubbhatānī”ti.
sn13.3:2.3.eng: Compared to the water in the confluence, it’s not nearly a hundredth, a thousandth, or a hundred thousandth part.”

sn13.3:2.4.eng: “In the same way, for a noble disciple, the suffering that’s over and done with is more …”

sn13.4:1.2.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yatthimā mahānadiyo saṃsandanti samenti, seyyathidaṃ—
sn13.4:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, there are places where the great rivers—the Ganges, Yamuna, Aciravatī, Sarabhū, and Mahī—join together and converge.

sn13.4:1.3.pli: gaṅgā yamunā aciravatī sarabhū mahī, taṃ udakaṃ parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya ṭhapetvā dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni.
sn13.4:1.3.eng: Suppose that water dried up and evaporated except for two or three drops.

sn13.4:1.5.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ, yaṃ vā sambhejjaudakaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ yāni vā dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni avasiṭṭhānī”ti?
sn13.4:1.5.eng: Which is more: the water in the confluence that has dried up and evaporated, or the two or three drops left?”

sn13.4:2.1.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ sambhejjaudakaṃ yadidaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ;
sn13.4:2.1.eng: “Sir, the water in the confluence that has dried up and evaporated is certainly more.

sn13.4:2.2.pli: appamattakāni dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni avasiṭṭhāni.
sn13.4:2.2.eng: The two or three drops left are tiny.

sn13.4:2.3.pli: Neva satimaṃ kalaṃ upenti na sahassimaṃ kalaṃ upenti na satasahassimaṃ kalaṃ upenti sambhejjaudakaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ upanidhāya dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni avasiṭṭhānī”ti.
sn13.4:2.3.eng: Compared to the water in the confluence that has dried up and evaporated, it’s not nearly a hundredth, a thousandth, or a hundred thousandth part.”

sn13.4:2.4.eng: “In the same way, for a noble disciple, the suffering that’s over and done with is more …”

sn13.5:1.2.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso mahāpathaviyā satta kolaṭṭhimattiyo guḷikā upanikkhipeyya.
sn13.5:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, suppose a person was to place seven clay balls the size of jujube seeds on the great earth.

sn13.5:1.4.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ, yā vā satta kolaṭṭhimattiyo guḷikā upanikkhittā yā vā mahāpathavī”ti?
sn13.5:1.4.eng: Which is more: the seven clay balls the size of jujube seeds, or the great earth?”

sn13.5:2.1.eng: “Sir, the great earth is certainly more.

sn13.5:2.2.eng: The seven clay balls the size of jujube seeds are tiny.

sn13.5:2.3.pli: Neva satimaṃ kalaṃ upenti na sahassimaṃ kalaṃ upenti na satasahassimaṃ kalaṃ upenti mahāpathaviṃ upanidhāya satta kolaṭṭhimattiyo guḷikā upanikkhittā”ti.
sn13.5:2.3.eng: Compared to the great earth, it’s not nearly a hundredth, a thousandth, or a hundred thousandth part.”

sn13.5:2.4.eng: “In the same way, for a noble disciple, the suffering that’s over and done with is more …”

sn13.6:1.2.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, mahāpathavī parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya, ṭhapetvā satta kolaṭṭhimattiyo guḷikā.
sn13.6:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, suppose the great earth was worn away and eroded except for seven clay balls the size of jujube seeds.

sn13.6:1.4.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ, yaṃ vā mahāpathaviyā parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ yā vā satta kolaṭṭhimattiyo guḷikā avasiṭṭhā”ti?
sn13.6:1.4.eng: Which is more: the great earth that has been worn away and eroded, or the seven clay balls the size of jujube seeds that are left?”

sn13.6:2.1.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ, mahāpathaviyā, yadidaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ;
sn13.6:2.1.eng: “Sir, the great earth that has been worn away and eroded is certainly more.

sn13.6:2.2.eng: The seven clay balls the size of jujube seeds are tiny.

sn13.6:2.3.pli: Neva satimaṃ kalaṃ upenti na sahassimaṃ kalaṃ upenti na satasahassimaṃ kalaṃ upenti mahāpathaviyā parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ upanidhāya satta kolaṭṭhimattiyo guḷikā avasiṭṭhā”ti.
sn13.6:2.3.eng: Compared to the great earth that has been worn away and eroded, it’s not nearly a hundredth, a thousandth, or a hundred thousandth part.”

sn13.6:2.4.eng: “In the same way, for a noble disciple, the suffering that’s over and done with is more …”

sn13.7:1.2.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso mahāsamuddato dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni uddhareyya.
sn13.7:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, suppose a man was to draw up two or three drops of water from the ocean.

sn13.7:1.4.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ, yāni vā dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni ubbhatāni yaṃ vā mahāsamudde udakan”ti?
sn13.7:1.4.eng: Which is more: the two or three drops drawn out or the water in the ocean?”

sn13.7:2.1.eng: “Sir, the water in the ocean is certainly more.

sn13.7:2.2.pli: appamattakāni dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni ubbhatāni.
sn13.7:2.2.eng: The two or three drops drawn out are tiny.

sn13.7:2.3.pli: Neva satimaṃ kalaṃ upenti na sahassimaṃ kalaṃ upenti na satasahassimaṃ kalaṃ upenti mahāsamudde udakaṃ upanidhāya dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni ubbhatānī”ti.
sn13.7:2.3.eng: Compared to the water in the ocean, it’s not nearly a hundredth, a thousandth, or a hundred thousandth part.”

sn13.7:2.4.eng: “In the same way, for a noble disciple, the suffering that’s over and done with is more …”

sn13.8:1.2.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, mahāsamuddo parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya, ṭhapetvā dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni.
sn13.8:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, suppose the water in the ocean dried up and evaporated except for two or three drops.

sn13.8:1.4.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ, yaṃ vā mahāsamudde udakaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ yāni vā dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni avasiṭṭhānī”ti?
sn13.8:1.4.eng: Which is more: the water in the ocean that has dried up and evaporated, or the two or three drops left?”

sn13.8:2.1.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ mahāsamudde udakaṃ, yadidaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ;
sn13.8:2.1.eng: “Sir, the water in the ocean that has dried up and evaporated is certainly more.

sn13.8:2.2.pli: appamattakāni dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni avasiṭṭhāni.
sn13.8:2.2.eng: The two or three drops left are tiny.

sn13.8:2.3.pli: Neva satimaṃ kalaṃ upenti na sahassimaṃ kalaṃ upenti na satasahassimaṃ kalaṃ upenti mahāsamudde udakaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ upanidhāya dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni avasiṭṭhānī”ti.
sn13.8:2.3.eng: Compared to the water in the ocean that has dried up and evaporated, it’s not nearly a hundredth, a thousandth, or a hundred thousandth part.”

sn13.8:2.4.eng: “In the same way, for a noble disciple, the suffering that’s over and done with is more …”

sn13.9:1.2.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso himavato pabbatarājassa satta sāsapamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā upanikkhipeyya.
sn13.9:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, suppose a person was to place seven pebbles the size of mustard seeds on the Himalayas, the king of mountains.

sn13.9:1.4.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ, yā vā satta sāsapamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā upanikkhittā yo vā himavā pabbatarājā”ti?
sn13.9:1.4.eng: Which is more: the seven pebbles the size of mustard seeds, or the Himalayas, the king of mountains?”

sn13.9:2.1.eng: “Sir, the Himalayas, the king of mountains, is certainly more.

sn13.9:2.2.eng: The seven pebbles the size of mustard seeds are tiny.

sn13.9:2.3.pli: Neva satimaṃ kalaṃ upenti na sahassimaṃ kalaṃ upenti na satasahassimaṃ kalaṃ upenti himavantaṃ pabbatarājānaṃ upanidhāya satta sāsapamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā upanikkhittā”ti.
sn13.9:2.3.eng: Compared to the Himalayas, it’s not nearly a hundredth, a thousandth, or a hundred thousandth part.”

sn13.9:2.4.eng: “In the same way, for a noble disciple, the suffering that’s over and done with is more …”

sn14.1:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the diversity of elements.
sn14.1:1.2.comm: The “elements” (dhātu) are the many different phenomena that can be observed in the world and in experience. These can be the various aspects of sense experience, diverse character types (SN 14.14–29), states of matter ((SN 14.30–39), or other things. Vedic dhātu has a special affinity for the numbers three (as in worlds) and seven. Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.5.1–3 discusses how food, water, and heat each break down into three elements.

sn14.1:1.3.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
sn14.1:1.3.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn14.1:1.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

sn14.1:2.1.eng: “And what is the diversity of elements?
sn14.1:2.1.comm: For nānatta (“diversity”), compare puthutta (“expansiveness”) at SN 12.48:5.1 and vemattatā (“disparity”) at SN 48.13:1.6. At MN 1:24.1, the Buddha taught “diversity” as the opposite fallacy to “oneness”; based on the diversity of sense experience, it interprets the world as irreducibly manifold. An example would be the Jains, who believed the world was made up of countless separate entities, a view criticized in Māṇḍūkya Upaniṣad 3.13 (nānātvaṁ nindyate). Both these fallacies take a particular mode of perception which is true in certain respects and make it into an absolute. The Buddha treats diversity as a way of analyzing experience, not as a metaphysical postulate.

sn14.1:2.2.pli: Cakkhudhātu rūpadhātu cakkhuviññāṇadhātu, sotadhātu saddadhātu sotaviññāṇadhātu, ghānadhātu gandhadhātu ghānaviññāṇadhātu, jivhādhātu rasadhātu jivhāviññāṇadhātu, kāyadhātu phoṭṭhabbadhātu kāyaviññāṇadhātu, manodhātu dhammadhātu manoviññāṇadhātu—
sn14.1:2.2.eng: The eye element, sight element, and eye consciousness element. The ear element, sound element, and ear consciousness element. The nose element, smell element, and nose consciousness element. The tongue element, taste element, and tongue consciousness element. The body element, touch element, and body consciousness element. The mind element, ideas element, and mind consciousness element.
sn14.1:2.2.comm: The chapter is structured in two “pentads” (pañcaka), a formalism that gained prominence in the Abhidhamma. The first discourse merely lists the eighteen elements. Subsequent discourses elaborate, each one introducing a new complexity. Discourses 2–5 treat the internal sense fields, while 6–10 treat the external sense fields. In this way the student is introduced to new concepts gradually, and can spend time contemplating each topic before the next is introduced.| For these eighteen elements, see MN 28:37.1, MN 115:4.8, and notes there.

sn14.1:2.3.eng: This is called the diversity of elements.”
